results.abstract: Brief reviews of additional children's books; drawing (S)
results.snippet: THE THIEF. By Megan Whalen Turner. Greenwillow. $15. (Ages 10 and up) Gen, the narrator, has been plucked from prison because the king's scholar needs a thief clever enough to pry an ancient treasure from the place where he thinks it is hidden. The...
results.lead_paragraph: THE THIEF. By Megan Whalen Turner. Greenwillow. $15. (Ages 10 and up) Gen, the narrator, has been plucked from prison because the king's scholar needs a thief clever enough to pry an ancient treasure from the place where he thinks it is hidden. The setting combines ancient and modern Greece. A 1997 Newbery Honor Book. HUSH! A Thai Lullaby. By Minfong Ho. Illustrated by Holly Meade. Orchard Books. $15.95. (Ages 2 to 6) A mother admonishes creatures small (a mosquito, a lizard), medium (a monkey) and large (a water buffalo, an elephant) to settle down and be quiet because her baby is sleeping. The illustrations are cut-paper collage and watercolor. A 1997 Caldecott Honor Book. DMITRI THE ASTRONAUT. Written and illustrated by Jon Agee. Michael di Capua/HarperCollins. $14.95. (Ages 3 and up) High in the heavens and down on earth, Dmitri the astronaut seeks friends. THE SANDY BOTTOM ORCHESTRA. By Garrison Keillor and Jenny Lind Nilsson. Hyperion. $14.95. (Ages 10 and up) Here's an appealing novel about a summer of classical music in a town called Sandy Bottom, which is somewhere in the Middle West, probably quite near Lake Wobegon. Rachel Green is a talented but lonely 14-year-old with eccentric parents. THE FRIENDS. By Kazumi Yumoto. Translated by Cathy Hirano. Farrar, Straus & Giroux. $15. (Ages 10 and up) The friends of the title are three young boys in contemporary Japan who snoop on an old neighborhood man who they think is dying. The winner of the 1997 Mildred Batchelder Award for translation. WHO WERE THE FOUNDING FATHERS? Two Hundred Years of Reinventing American History. By Steven H. Jaffe. Holt. $16.95. (Ages 10 and up) This nicely provocative book begins with a tone-setting discussion of the 56 signers of the Declaration of Independence, showing how they have been seen, from different points of view, as traitors, hypocrites or patriots.

results.abstract: Wildwood, NJ, is trove of authentic seaside boardwalk-town architecture and kitsch of late 1950's; Kent State University architecture students are documenting Wildwood for Library of Congress; Jack Morey, whose family has operated amusement park piers there for years, comments (S)

headline.main: Real Beach Kitsch, Not the Fake Stuff

results.snippet: AS amusement parks go, Disney World gives me the willies: All those preternaturally rapturous people wearing shirts plastered with advertisements, strewing disposable incomes across manicured Technicolor midways, while that dreadful mouse-face beams...
results.lead_paragraph: AS amusement parks go, Disney World gives me the willies: All those preternaturally rapturous people wearing shirts plastered with advertisements, strewing disposable incomes across manicured Technicolor midways, while that dreadful mouse-face beams down over all like a penitentiary's searchlight. A day of this is enough to send me to the phone book for the number of an exterminator. One more rendition of ''It's a Small World After All,'' and I'm ready to call Amnesty International. All things considered then, on those infrequent occasions when the urge to visit an amusement park hits me, I'd rather be in Wildwood, New Jersey's most exuberantly declasse boardwalk resort. As the millenium approaches in a world where entertainment is all, Wildwood is the anti-Disney.

results.abstract: Morgan Park High School Band, predominantly African-American group of musicians and twirlers and flag wavers, marches in South Side Irish Parade in Chicago; is greeted with warm reception, compared with 1996, when they were greeted with taunts, jeers and racial epithets; photo (M)

headline.main: Peaceful Parade After Spasm of Race Hatred Last Year

results.snippet: Entry No. 36 in today's South Side Irish Parade was the Morgan Park High School marching band, a predominately African-American group of musicians and twirlers and flag wavers.    The school is the alma mater of Dr. Mae C. Jemison, the astronaut, and...
results.lead_paragraph: Entry No. 36 in today's South Side Irish Parade was the Morgan Park High School marching band, a predominately African-American group of musicians and twirlers and flag wavers. The school is the alma mater of Dr. Mae C. Jemison, the astronaut, and its band has marched for years in events all over the city, including the Irish parade, one of the country's largest neighborhood celebrations in honor of St. Patrick and the Irish.

results.snippet: INTERNATIONAL   A3-15    Clinton and Yeltsin Meet In Crucial Helsinki Summit  President Clinton met with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Helsinki, Finland, starting a round of crucial meetings on the post-cold-war security structure of...
results.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Clinton and Yeltsin Meet In Crucial Helsinki Summit President Clinton met with President Boris N. Yeltsin of Russia in Helsinki, Finland, starting a round of crucial meetings on the post-cold-war security structure of Europe. Mr. Clinton conveyed American willingness to make further concessions in a new nuclear arms treaty, and Mr. Yeltsin adopted a conciliatory tone while remaining opposed to the eastward expansion of NATO. A1

results.abstract: John Reznikoff, collector of stamps and rare documents from Stamford, Conn, also collects samples of hair from famous people; he has hair samples from Abraham Lincoln, Elvis Presley and Marilyn Monroe; they are among more than 100 hair samples he has gathered and insured for $1 million; photo (M)

headline.main: Legacy of a Hank of Hair

results.snippet: JOHN REZNIKOFF doesn't know what killed Marilyn Monroe 35 years ago, but he just might hold some important evidence.    And if the day ever comes when a human being can be cloned from DNA, as many scientists suspect can be done, then Mr. Reznikoff...
results.lead_paragraph: JOHN REZNIKOFF doesn't know what killed Marilyn Monroe 35 years ago, but he just might hold some important evidence. And if the day ever comes when a human being can be cloned from DNA, as many scientists suspect can be done, then Mr. Reznikoff may be a wanted man because safely ensconced in his tightly secured Stamford office and at least three sturdy bank vaults are his treasures: hair. Not the Vidal Sassoon kind, but actual snips from the tresses of those who once walked this earth and now are immortalized in our history: Abraham Lincoln, Napoleon, Albert Einstein, a beheaded Charles I of England, a 3,000-year-old mummified nobleman -- even Elvis. They are among the more than 100 hair samples that Mr. Reznikoff, a collector of stamps and rare documents, has gathered and insured for $1 million. Despite offers on various samples ranging from $50,000 to $100,000, the collection is not for sale.

results.snippet: HARTFORD BALLET      This week at The Bushnell in Hartford the Hartford Ballet will present a program devoted to the choregraphy of its director, Kirk Peterson. Under the overall title of ''Director's Choice,'' Mr. Peterson has selected five ballets...
results.lead_paragraph: HARTFORD BALLET This week at The Bushnell in Hartford the Hartford Ballet will present a program devoted to the choregraphy of its director, Kirk Peterson. Under the overall title of ''Director's Choice,'' Mr. Peterson has selected five ballets created between 1984 and 1994, displaying a variety of styles and content.
